Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Situation2: They encounter a customer trying to return an item without a receipt and need to apply the store’s return policy.
Story: I glanced at my phone during my break, a smile tugging at my lips as I read my girlfriend’s message: “Let’s have dinner together tonight? We finally have time!” I’d promised her we’d make the most of our free evenings this week, just the two of us, no distractions. I wanted to be the boyfriend she deserved—attentive, present, making her feel special. But as my shift resumed, a customer approached the register, frustration etched on her face. She wanted to return a blender, but she didn’t have a receipt. Store policy was clear: no returns without proof of purchase. My manager had drilled it into us—no exceptions, even if the customer got upset. I could feel the tension building inside me. If I followed the rules, I’d likely delay closing, making me late for our date. If I bent the rules, I’d risk my job. My phone buzzed again in my pocket, her name lighting up the screen. I stood there, torn between being the reliable boyfriend she hoped for and the responsible cashier my boss expected.
